summary: AI is increasingly embedded in telemedicine platforms to triage incoming patient queries with NLP chatbots, guide remote clinicians via decision-support algorithms that analyze EMR or imaging data in real time, and predict adherence or deterioration by continuously processing data from wearables and home tests. These tools are already streamlining virtual HIV-PrEP programs in countries such as Kenya and Nigeria, powering dermatology and radiology e-consults across U.S. and European health systems, and supporting chronic-disease monitoring in rural India and Brazil. By automating routine tasks and flagging high-risk cases early, AI makes remote care faster, more personalized, and scalable despite workforce or geographic constraints.
